docs.lead_paragraph: A Medicaid overhaul in New York has shifted $6 billion in public spending on long-term services for disabled and aged people to managed care companies.

headline.main: Medicaid Shift Fuels Rush for Profitable Clients
headline.print_headline: Medicaid Shift Fuels Rush for Profitable Clients

docs.abstract: Ambitious Medicaid overhaul in New York has shifted $6 billion in public spending on long-term services for disabled and aged people to managed care companies; state's goal was savings but changes set off scramble among companies and service providers to enroll clients requiring minimal care and many frail people with greater needs were dropped.
docs.snippet: A Medicaid overhaul in New York has shifted $6 billion in public spending on long-term services for disabled and aged people to managed care companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: The goal was cost savings, but the state’s sweeping changes in Medicaid spending on long-term services set off a stampede in recent years by managed care companies for low-risk, high-profit enrollees.
docs.snippet: The goal was cost savings, but the state’s sweeping changes in Medicaid spending on long-term services set off a stampede in recent years by managed care companies for low-risk, high-profit enrollees.

byline.original: Produced by NINA BERNSTEIN and EBA HAMID

docs.lead_paragraph: Across Central America, a kidney disease has killed at least 20,000 people over a decade and is so poorly understood that it does not have a universally agreed upon name.

headline.main: Deadly Illness in Nicaragua Baffles Experts
headline.print_headline: Nicaragua Sugar Workers Fall to Illness That Baffles Experts

docs.abstract: Disease that affects kidneys has killed at least 20,000 people in Central America over past decade, particularly affecting Nicaragua's sugar cane workers; illness is so poorly understood that it still does not have universally agreed upon name.
docs.snippet: Across Central America, a kidney disease has killed at least 20,000 people over a decade and is so poorly understood that it does not have a universally agreed upon name.

docs.lead_paragraph: The board of the broken Massachusetts health insurance exchange voted to buy new software to help people enroll in coverage, while preparing to join the federal marketplace if necessary.

headline.main: Massachusetts Pushes Fix for State Health Exchange
headline.print_headline: Massachusetts Pushes Fix for State Health Exchange

docs.abstract: Board of broken Massachusetts health insurance exchange votes to buy new software to help people enroll in coverage, while also preparing to join the federal marketplace if there is a delay in getting the system up and running.
docs.snippet: The board of the broken Massachusetts health insurance exchange voted to buy new software to help people enroll in coverage, while preparing to join the federal marketplace if necessary.

headline.main: Pick to Replace Sebelius Draws Senators’ Praise at Confirmation Hearing
headline.print_headline: Pick to Replace Sebelius Draws Senators’ Praise at Confirmation Hearing

docs.abstract: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, Pres Obama’s nominee to replace Kathleen Sebelius as secretary of health and human services, charms senators at surprisingly cordial confirmation hearing, even picking up a couple of Republican endorsements.

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers are human. That means sometimes they have needs that take them away from work for extended periods of time. Babies, illnesses and even sabbaticals can mean a long time away from a job and a paycheck, too.
